facts.fact: Capybaras are the largest rodents in the world.
They are native to South America.
Capybaras are highly social animals and live in groups.
They can weigh up to 140 pounds (63 kg).
Capybaras are excellent swimmers.
They have webbed feet to help them swim.
Capybaras can stay submerged underwater for up to five minutes.
They eat grasses, aquatic plants, and fruit.
Capybaras have a gentle and calm temperament.
They are preyed upon by jaguars, anacondas, and caimans.
Capybaras communicate through barks, whistles, clicks, and purrs.
They are diurnal, mostly active during the day.
Capybaras have scent glands on their noses.
They also have scent glands on their anal region for marking territory.
Capybaras live near water bodies like rivers, lakes, and swamps.
They are herbivores.
Capybaras practice coprophagy, eating their own feces to digest food better.
Their lifespan in the wild is around 8-10 years.
In captivity, they can live up to 12 years.
Capybaras have partially webbed feet for swimming and walking on soft ground.
They can weigh anywhere from 77 to 146 pounds (35-66 kg).
Capybaras can grow up to 4.3 feet (1.3 m) long.
They have small ears and eyes positioned high on their heads.
This head positioning allows them to see and hear while mostly submerged.
Capybaras are known to be friendly with other animals.
They often interact peacefully with birds, monkeys, and even cats.
Capybaras can run up to 35 km/h (22 mph) on land for short distances.
They mark their territory with scent glands.
A group of capybaras is called a 'herd' or 'group'.
Group sizes range from 10 to 20 individuals but can be larger in wetter areas.
Capybaras are known to have mutual grooming behaviors.
They often sleep in the sun, partially submerged in water.
They are herbivores but occasionally consume their own feces to extract extra nutrients.
Capybara babies are called 'pups'.
Pups are born with teeth already visible.
Female capybaras give birth to 2-8 pups per litter.
Gestation period is around 150 days.
Pups can eat grass within a week of birth.
Capybaras are known to be very tolerant of humans.
They are sometimes kept as pets in some countries.
Capybaras are classified as 'Least Concern' by the IUCN.
They have thick, coarse fur.
Their fur is reddish-brown to grayish in color.
Capybaras have four toes on their front feet and three on their hind feet.
They are capable of making a variety of vocalizations to communicate.
Barking is a common alarm signal.
Purring signals contentment and social bonding.
They live in territories that can span several acres.
Capybaras are mostly found in countries like Brazil, Venezuela, and Colombia.
They avoid dense forests, preferring open areas near water.
Capybaras have a slow metabolism.
Their teeth grow continuously, which helps them grind tough vegetation.
Capybaras have a high social hierarchy within their groups.
Dominant males guard the territory and lead the herd.
They use saliva to scent-mark during mating season.
Capybaras can survive both in wet and dry seasons.
They are sensitive to cold and rarely found in high-altitude regions.
They are crepuscular in some areas, active during early morning and late afternoon.
Capybaras can communicate distress through high-pitched whines.
They are preyed upon less when in groups due to collective vigilance.
Capybaras have been known to interact with humans in eco-tourism areas.
Their social grooming strengthens bonds and reduces stress.
Capybaras often sleep with their heads resting on each other.
They enjoy mud baths which help protect from parasites and sunburn.
Capybaras rarely fight; disputes are usually resolved through posturing.
They can hold their breath for several minutes while hiding underwater.
Capybaras are adaptable and can live in wetlands, savannas, and riversides.
They are sometimes used in therapy programs due to their calm nature.
Capybaras are mostly silent when grazing but vocal when threatened.
They groom each other using their teeth and tongue.
Their eyes, ears, and nostrils are positioned on top of their head for surveillance while swimming.
Capybaras are capable of remembering past threats and avoiding them.
They have been featured in many internet memes for their friendly demeanor.
Capybaras sometimes form alliances with birds that eat ticks off their skin.
They are excellent at finding shallow water to escape predators.
Capybaras have a low-pitched vocal range for group communication.
Their social structure reduces stress and increases survival rates.
Capybaras are crepuscular and diurnal depending on the environment.
Males sometimes fight using their large front teeth during breeding season.
Females usually dominate social grooming sessions.
Capybaras have strong hind legs for swimming and running.
They are occasionally hunted for meat and hide in some regions.
Capybaras can recognize individual humans and animals.
They are important for ecosystem balance by grazing on aquatic plants.
Capybaras are herbivores that help maintain wetland vegetation.
They often rest together in the middle of the day.
Capybaras can eat up to 8 pounds of grass per day.
Their teeth are orange due to high iron content.
Capybaras have adapted to living near humans in rural areas.
They have been known to interact peacefully with dogs.
Capybaras have minimal body odor compared to other rodents.
They often migrate short distances to find food and water.
Capybaras enjoy being in water for both cooling and safety.
Young capybaras can swim within days of birth.
Capybaras use teeth chattering as a social signal.
They are non-aggressive and avoid confrontation when possible.
Capybaras can tolerate periods of drought by moving to wetter areas.
They are considered semi-aquatic mammals.
Capybaras have a keen sense of smell to detect predators.
They are iconic animals in South American culture and folklore.
